Glycerol carbonate (GLC) offers a range of benefits including biodegradability, versatility, and its potential for carbon capture and utilization. Base catalysts play a crucial role for GLC synthesis by facilitating the activation of reactants, enhancing nucleophilicity, accelerating reaction kinetics, and enabling catalyst regeneration. In this study, metal–organic framework (MOF) derived hybrid structure, CaO-MgO@Al2O3, was developed as a base catalyst to promote transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to form GLC. The results show that hydrothermal plus wet-impregnation routes formed the hybrid nanostructure with homogenously dispersed Ca, Mg and Al elements. Further, the synthesized catalysts showed significantly high specific surface area and basicity (2.656 mmol g−1). High selectivity (>99 %) and high GLC yield (96.2 %; 208.9 mmol g-cat−1) were achievable. This study demonstrated the rational design concept of MOF-derived hybrid structures used in the enhancement of base catalysis for transesterification of DMC to GLC, offering an effective solution with mild reaction conditions and high conversion. Graphical Abstract Keywords Metal-organic framework Transesterification Catalysis Glycerol carbonate Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide, as a critical greenhouse gas, can be used for the production of various chemicals (e.g., methanol, formic acid) [1–3]. One attractive method for CO2 utilization is producing dialkyl carbonate (DRC) via carboxylation of alcohols, which yields high-value carbonate chemicals while reducing of CO2 [4–7]. Among these, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is one of the most important and widely discussed products among these CO2-derived DRC [6,8–10], which stands out as an environmental-friendly chemical due to its non-toxic and biodegradable characteristics [8,11,12]. DMC can be used as green reagent/raw material in alcohol transesterification due to its versatile chemical reactivity [13–15]. However, DMC production via CO2 has a low yield (i.e., equilibrium conversion ∼0.3 % at molar ratio of CO2: methanol = 4, under 120 °C and 50 bar). In this regard, the two-stage carboxylation of alcohol, combining reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction [16,17] and oxidative carbonation is used, as shown in Scheme 1 (Step 1) [18]. Given the limitations in direct CO2 utilization for DRC production, transesterification of DMC followed by DRC production offers a versatile alternative. Parallel to these efforts, increased biodiesel production has led an excess of glycerol [19,20], prompting research into valuable derivatives like glycerol carbonate (GLC) [21,22]. GLC, the representative DMC-derived material, is highly attractive and can be used as a polar, high-boiling point solvent, a surfactant component, and an intermediate for many kinds of polymers such as polyesters, polycarbonates, polyamides [23,24]. Specially, it also can be ultilized in energy related applications such as fuel additive and green electrolyte solvent in lithium batteries [20,23,25,26]. There are many routes to synthesize GLC [26,27], possibly from the phosgene route [27], carbonylation of glycerol with urea [28], oxidation carbonylation of glycerol with CO [29], direct carbonylation of glycerol with CO2 [30,31] and transesterification route. Particularly, the transesterification of DMC with glycerol to GLC [25,27,32] is an economical solution [23,25,26,33]. As displayed in Scheme 1 (Step 2), the by-product in the transesterification of DMC to GLC is methanol, a major industrial chemical, which can be easily separated after the reaction due to the remarkable difference in volatility compared with that of DMC, glycerol and GLC. Following a purification process, this methanol can be reused for the DMC synthesis (Step 1 of Scheme 1). This recycling approach helps in reducing the overall consumption of methanol, making the process more sustainable and economically viable. Besides, implementing a reaction system with integrated distillation for methanol separation during the reaction process is a viable option. This approach not only isolates methanol but also accelerates the forward reaction of the reversible transesterification of DMC to GLC. However, a base catalyst plays a vital role in enhancing the rate and selectivity of the reaction [23,26]. Both homogenous and heterogenous catalysts can be employed to convert DMC and glycerol to GLC. Homogeneous catalysts (such as K2CO3, Na2CO3, KHCO3, CH3OK, NaOH [32]) often provide a more effective catalysis route, but the necessities in the separation and purification of reaction products result in elevated production costs [32,34]. Since, the catalyst recovery and recycling processes are easier and straightforward in heterogeneous catalysis, it is often preferred for green, large-scale industrial processes. The utilization of heterogeneous catalysts such as CaO [33], Mg-Al hydrotalcite [35], KNO3-CaO [36], and several alkali and alkaline-earth metals were demonstrated as catalysts for the synthesis of GLC from DMC and glycerol [26]. Although catalysts such as CaO, alkali and alkaline-earth metals exhibit high catalytic efficiency due to their strong basicity, they possess low surface areas and easily tend to leach into the reaction mixture [37]. Additionally, catalysts such as CaO and Mg-Al hydrotalcite can deactivate during reactions due to structural changes. Consequently, hybrid structures have been developed to improve the properties and stability of base catalysts in the transesterification of DMC to GLC. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their derived materials are of great interest for catalytic applications attributable to their remarkable characteristics, such as high specific surface area, high porosity and compositional versatility [38–40]. The structural and functional characteristics of MOFs can be easily adjusted at the molecular level by introducing new functionalities into the framework [41,42]. This aspect has attracted interest for catalytic applications, which aim to develop highly efficient catalysts for various reactions [43–45]. Former studies have demonstrated the success of using MOF and MOF-derived material for the heterogeneous catalysis of transesterification. For example, Yang et al. investigated the performance of catalysts derived from Zn-MOF (ZIF-8), specifically MgO@Zn-MOF and MgO@ZnO, in transesterification of soybean oil to biodiesel [43]. This work showcased the remarkable efficacy of these hybrid nanostructures obtained from MOFs, supported by comprehensive material characterization. Notably, these catalysts exhibited superior catalytic activity when compared to MgO and ZIF-8 individually. With this background, the objective of the study is to develop high-performance catalyst derived from MOF, for transesterification of DMC to GLC (Step 2 of Scheme 1). MIL-53(Al), an Al-MOF with a flexible three-dimensional (3D) framework featuring one-dimensional rhombic-shaped channels, are employed in this work, in which the structure is created by linking trans chains of corner-sharing AlO4(OH)2 octahedra with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate groups [44,46]. Alumina derived from MIL-53(Al) exhibits specific porous properties, making it a promising candidate for applications as catalyst supports [47]. Additionally, alumina is an effective support for base active species in this reaction [37]. CaO and MgO are chosen as the active components of the base catalyst, which has been proved to have good catalytic activity over various transesterification reactions [24,33,43,48,49]. Hence, the precursors of MgO and/or CaO are encapsulated into the Al-MOF and then, their corresponding MOF-derived products (MgO@Al2O3 and CaO-MgO@Al2O3) obtained through a facile and controllable synthesis method. It is expected that the MOF-derived design significantly enhances the specific surface area and basicity of the Mg-Al and Ca-Mg-Al hybrid nanostructures which can greatly contribute the better performance and the cyclic stability of the resultant catalysts in comparison with the literature reported catalysts. Complementary materials analyses are employed to study the properties of the newly synthesized catalysts. Activity tests and cyclic stability tests are conducted to evaluate the relationship between catalytic performance and material properties of the synthesized catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Magnesium acetate tetrahydrate (98%, Showa Chemical Industry Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) and calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (98%, Showa Chemical Industry Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) were used as Mg precursor and Ca precursor, respectively. Aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (98%, Showa Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.) and terephthalic acid (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 99+%, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc., U.S.A.) were used to synthesize the Al-MOF. Aluminum oxide nanopowder (nominal diameter: 13 nm; Uni-Onward Corp., Taipei, Taiwan, ROC) was used in the composite nanostructure. Methanol (99.9%, Aencore Chemical Pty., Ltd., Australia) was used as a solvent to dissolve Mg and Ca precursors. Dimethyl carbonate (99%, Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd., Lancashire, U.K.) and glycerol (98%, Union Chemical Works Ltd., Taiwan) were used as the reactants. Glycerol 1,2-carbonate (>90%, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) was used as the standard in catalytic studies. 2.2 Synthesis of Al-MOF and MOF-derived hybrid nanostructures Scheme 2 illustrates the fabrication of Al-MOF and Al-MOF-derived hybrid nanostructures through a controlled synthesis process (i.e., using MgO@Al2O3 as representative). Firstly, Al-MOF (MIL-53(Al)) was synthesized via hydrothermal process [44]. A mixture containing 14.04 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O, 3.12 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) and 54 mL of deionized water, with a molar ratio of Al:BDC:H2O = 2:1:160, was introduced into a reactor and heated to 190 °C for 12 h under autogenous pressure, resulted in the formation of MIL-53(Al) colloids through self-assembly. Subsequently, the white as synthesized product (MIL-53(Al)as) was separated by filtration, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 150 °C for 17 h. Next, the encapsulation of Mg and Ca was done by incipient wetness impregnation method, in which the precursors with desired mass ratios were dissolved in 10 mL of methanol and mixed with Al-MOF [43]. The resulting mixture was then dried overnight at 100 °C. Finally, the dried products underwent calcination under air flow (0.5 L min−1) at various calcination temperatures (T cal) ranging from 550 to 650 °C, leading to the formation of MgO@Al2O3 and CaO-MgO@Al2O3 (Route A). Besides, for comparison, MgO catalyst was synthesized by direct decomposition of magnesium salt (i.e., denoted as MgO-P). Also, 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP were prepared by impregnating Mg and Ca precursors onto the commercial Al2O3 (nominal diameter: 13 nm) (Route B). The list of the synthesized samples and their details such as synthesis route, calcination temperature and mass fraction of Mg (W Mg), Al (W Al), Ca (W Ca) are shown in Table 1. Out of the twelve samples, nine were prepared by MOF-derived hybrid nanostructures (Route A) with different calcination temperatures (at 650 °C and 550 °C). Among the four samples that were calcined at 650 °C, different weight fractions of MgO were prepared to assess the impact on catalyst performance. For comparison, the MgO-P, 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP samples were also synthesized via Route B. 2.3 Material characterization Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; SDT Q600, TA Instrument, DE, U.S.A.) of Mg precursor, Ca precursor and MIL-53(Al) were performed in air. About 10 mg of samples was used, and the temperature was set to increase from 30 °C to 800 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under an air flow of 100 mL min−1. Morphology and elemental distribution of the synthesized catalysts were determined by a field emission-scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Hitachi SU8010, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the synthesized samples were measured using an X-ray powder diffractometer (D2 Phaser, Brucker, Billerica, MA, U.S.A.) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), which was operated at 30 kV, 10 mA, using a scanning rate of 2.0° min−1. The specific surface area (S BET) and pore volume (V pore) of the synthesized samples were determined using a surface area analyzer (ASAP 2060, Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, U.S.A.). Here, S BET was calculated based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of 0.05 < P/P0 < 0.3 (i.e., mesopore analyses). Prior to the measurements, the catalysts were degassed over 8 h at 120 °C. The assessment of surface basicity was conducted using the CO2-based temperature-programmed desorption method (CO2-TPD, ASAP 2920, Micrometrics). Approximately 100 mg of the sample was initially preheated under a helium gas flow at 200 °C. After cooling down to 35 °C, CO2 was introduced using a mixture of 10 % CO2 and 90 % helium. Subsequently, the release of CO2 was monitored and recorded by heating the sample up to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under helium flow. 2.4 Catalytic activity test Tranesterification of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to glycerol carbonate (GLC) was implemented in a 300 mL stainless autoclave reactor equipped with a stirrer. A mixture of 5.52 g of glycerol and 10.81 g of DMC [molar ratio of DMC to glycerol (R) = 2:1] was introduced into the reactor with 5 wt% of the catalyst (i.e., with respect to glycerol). This excess DMC serves the dual purpose of reducing the viscosity of the mixture and enhancing miscibility, thereby concurrently addressing the challenge of chemical reaction equilibrium. The reaction mixture was stirred with 600 rpm stirring speed, at 100 °C and 26 bar, for 4 h. The final product was analyzed by a gas chromatography installed with a flame ionization detector (GC-FID, 7820 A, Agilent Inc., Santa Clara, CA, U.S.A.) equipped with 100 % polyethylene glycol column (DB-WAX Columns; 60 m in length, 0.32 mm in inner diameter, 0.5 µm in film thickness; Agilent Inc.). The column temperature was initially maintained at 60 °C for 1 min. Then, the temperature was increased to 140 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 and held for 5 min, followed by heating to a final temperature of 240 °C at 10 °C min−1 and kept constant for 15 min. The column pressure was set at 25 psi. The injector and detector temperatures were set to 250 °C and 275 °C, respectively. An internal standard of butanol (99.4 %) was used in the analysis. The catalytic performance of the transesterification of DMC with glycerol to GLC was evaluated by the DMC conversion (X DMC), glycerol conversion (X Gly), yield (Y GLC) and selectivity (S GLC) of GLC. And, these parameters were calculated by using the following Eqs. (1–4): (1) X DMC (%) = (MDMC,feed – MDMC,final)/MDMC,feed x 100% (2) X Gly (%) = (MGly,feed – MGly,final)/MGly,feed x 100% (3) Y GLC (%) = MGLC, produced /MGly,feed x 100% (4) S GLC (%) = MGLC,produced /(M Gly,feed – MGly,final) x 100% Here, MDMC, MGly and MGLC (unit: mmol) are number of moles of DMC, glycerol and GLC, respectively. In the recyclability analysis, centrifugation was employed to separate the spent catalyst from the liquid phase after each run. Subsequently, the spent catalyst underwent multiple washes with ethanol and then dried at 100 °C overnight. The activity tests for the recycled catalysts were carried out under optimized conditions. Turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) for the production of GLC were calculated using Eqs. (5–6): (5) TON = (n Gly,feed × X Gly × N Gly)/(100 × m cat) (6) TOF (h−1) = TON/t Here, n Gly,feed (unit: mol) is the initial molar of glycerol, N Gly (unit: g mol−1) is molecular weight of glycerol, m cat (unit: g-cat) is the mass of catalyst used in the reaction, and t (unit: h) is the reaction time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterization of MOF-derived, Mg-Al and Ca-Mg-Al hybrid nanostructures Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the MOF-derived Mg-Al hybrid nanostructures calcined at 650 °C (Fig. 1a), and the MOF-derived Mg-Al, Ca-Mg-Al hybrid nanostructures and comparison samples calcined at 550 °C (Fig. 1b). The diffraction peaks corresponding to MgO and γ-Al2O3 were clearly discerned in the MgO@Al2O3 samples, particularly those calcined at 650 °C. The peaks located at 2 θ = 36.8°, 42.6°, 61.9°, 74.5° and 78.5° were attributed to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes of MgO, respectively. The peaks for γ-Al2O3 were recognized at 31.6°, 44.4° and 65.2°, which were attributed to (220), (400) and (440) planes of γ-Al2O3, respectively. This observation confirms the successful formation of desired products through thermal decomposition of the precursors. For samples loaded CaO, characteristic peaks were identified at 32.0°, 37.3° and 53.6°, which were attributed to (111), (200) and (220) planes of CaO. It is to be noted that the peaks corresponding to Al2O3 were not observed for the MOF-derived samples obtained at 550 °C, which may be due to its low crystallinity. Besides, an additional phase of MgAl2O4 (the spinel phase), which peaks at 2θ = 19.0° and 59.6°, in correspondence to (111) and (511) planes, respectively, was observed in the MgO@Al2O3-650. Whereas, in the CaO-containing samples, the additional CaAl2O4 phase at 2θ =18.0°, 29.2°, 30.5°, 31.4°. 35.1° and 35.8° was obtained along with regular peaks for CaO and MgO. Further, the increase in CaO loading improved the intensity of XRD peaks of CaO and CaAl2O4 phase in the CaO-containing samples. Since the calcination was carried out under atmospheric conditions, the decorated carbon material was not observed in the samples. Additional semi-quantitative analyses of the compositions of the samples using Rietveld refinement are given in Section S6 of Supplementary material. In the case of comparing samples of 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP, the XRD patterns showed clear peaks for MgO, γ-Al2O3, CaO and CaAl2O4. Moreover, the samples derived from the Al-MOF exhibited smaller MgO crystallite size (d c,MgO) compared to MgO-P sample (obtained from direct decomposition of the Mg precursor), which were likely attributed to the inclusion of Al2O3 in the MOF-derived samples ( Table 2). As far as the samples having the same mass fraction are concerned, the samples obtained at 550 °C exhibited smaller d c,MgO value than that of the samples calcined at 650 °C (for instance, d c,MgO value of 40MgO@Al2O3-550 is 11.2 nm, which is smaller than that of 40MgO@Al2O3-650 sample, d c,MgO = 15.7 nm). Interestingly, both the MgO and CaO crystallite sizes of the MOF-derived samples obtained at 550 °C were smaller than the samples prepared by commercial Al2O3 NPs, demonstrating the incorporation of Al2O3 (particularly through Al-MOF as an Al2O3 precursor) serves to mitigate the sintering and aggregation of MgO and CaO during calcination. Consequently, the Al-MOF-derived catalyst reduced the crystallite sizes and enhanced the dispersion of metals, which were further evaluated through SEM-EDS results. Next, the specific surface area (S BET) and total pore volume (V pore) of the synthesized samples were analyzed and summarized in Table 2. Notably, all samples derived from Al-MOF exhibited significantly higher S BET and V pore values than MgO-P. In the case of MgO@Al2O3-650 samples, the increase in Mg content (W Mg) resulted a decrease in S BET from 178 to 87.1 m2 g−1. In comparison to the similar samples obtained at different temperatures (MgO@Al2O3-650 and MgO@Al2O3-550), the decrease in T cal improved the S BET values [from 87.1 (for 40MgO@Al2O3-650) to 112.9 m2 g−1 (for 40MgO@Al2O3-550)]. Similarly, the V pore increased from 0.36 to 0.53 cm3 g−1 as T cal decreased from 650 to 550 °C. These findings suggest that reducing the MgO content in Al-MOF-derived samples and lowering T cal resulted in higher S BET and V pore values. This can be attributed to the formation of smaller-sized MgO particles and the absence of MgO and Al2O3 crystallite aggregation, preventing the formation of a spinel phase. For samples obtained at 550 °C, CaO-MgO@Al2O3 samples exhibited a lower S BET value compared to that of MgO@Al2O3 samples, attributable to the formation of CaAl2O4 phase [50]. Furthermore, an increase in the Ca loading (W Ca) decreased the S BET and V pore values. Consequently, among the MOF-derived samples, 40CaO@Al-MOF-derived sample exhibited the lowest S BET and V pore. In addition, comparing to the non MOF-deriving samples, 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP showed lower S BET and V pore values than that of the Al-MOF-derived samples under the same elemental composition and calcination temperature. The Al2O3 derived from Al-MOF (192.4 m2 g−1) exhibited a significantly higher SBET than commercial Al2O3 (101.6 m2 g−1), possibly attributable to the retention of some porosity during calcination [38,39]. As shown in Figure S2 of Supplementary material, the presence of smaller mesopores (3.5–4.5 nm) of MOF-derived Al2O3 are linked to the micropores in Al-MOF, likely due to the decomposition of BDC ligands in Al-MOF. The inorganic units of Al-MOF formed crystalline sheet-like alumina with ordered mesoporous channels, contributing to the larger S BET and V pore of Al2O3 derived from Al-MOF [47,51]. The morphology and components of the synthesized materials were evaluated by SEM image accompanied by EDS elemental mapping which are displayed in Fig. 2 and Figures S4&S5 (Supplementary material). SEM images are presented for four representative samples (40MgO@Al2O3-650, 40MgO@Al2O3-550, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550, 40CaO@Al2O3-550). The SEM images revealed the formation of micron-sized particles for all the synthesized samples. Generally, all samples maintained their parent (uncalcined Al-MOF) morphology as shown in Figure S3 (Supplementary material). The EDS mapping results showed that Mg and Al were uniformly distributed throughout all the MgO@Al2O3 samples, indicating the homogeneous elemental distributions. Similarly, CaO-loading samples revealed the uniform distributions of Ca, Mg, and Al elements, confirming that the hydrothermal plus wet-impregnation routes were successfully applied to synthesize Mg-Al and Ca-Mg-Al hybrid structures with homogenously dispersed elements. Finally, CO2-TPD was employed to assess the basicity of the synthesized samples. Figs. 3a and 3b depict the CO2-TPD profiles for the samples calcined at 650 and 550 °C, respectively. The figures showed distinct peaks for CO2 desorption occurring in three temperature ranges: 60–200 °C (α), 200–400 °C (β), and >400 °C (γ). The α sites involve surface hydroxides with weak basic strengths, the β sites are associated with surface oxygen anions (such as Al3+-O2-, Mg2+-O2-, and Ca2+-O2-) displaying medium basicity, and the γ sites represent the strong basic sites corresponding to isolated O2- anions [43,49]. As shown in Table 3, the Al-MOF-derived sample exhibited a substantial increase in the total basicity than that of the MgO-P sample (Fig. 3a), rising from 112.5 to 1264.1 μmol g−1. These results indicated that the inclusion of Al2O3 effectively improved the basicity of samples. Besides, an increase in MgO loading in MgO@Al2O3 samples led to an increase in the total basicity. Furthermore, the enhanced basicity observed with decreasing T cal could be attributed to the increase in S BET value (resulting in a decrease d c, MgO). In summary, the use of MOF as a template in catalyst synthesis led to an overall increase in the catalyst's total basicity, primarily attributed to the augmented dispersion of MgO resulting from the increase in specific surface area. On the other hand, the introduction of Ca into the catalysts increased the basicity of the sample, especially the strong basic sites attributed to isolated O2- anions. By comparing Ca-loading samples and conventional MgO@Al-MOF-derived samples, it is clear that the basicity of the samples was enhanced by adding CaO. However, this enhancement in basicity was accompanied by a reduction in surface area compared to conventional MgO@Al2O3 samples. As summarized in Table 3, the total medium basic site decreased with increased Ca and reduced Mg content, whereas the strong basic site rose remarkably. In comparison with the non-MOF-deriving samples of the same composition, as depicted in Fig. 3, both 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP- exhibited immeasurably lower total basicity values, with the total basicity sites of 710.2 μmol g−1 and 798.6 μmol g−1, respectively. This disparity is primarily attributed to the diminished S BET and V pore values of the catalyst. Although the total basicity of 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP is not notably high, the presence of CaO in the catalyst leads to an expansion of strong basic sites. 3.2 Catalytic activity tests After the complete characterization, the MOF-derived Mg-Al and Ca-Mg-Al hybrid nanostructure samples were employed in the transesterification of DMC to GLC reaction. The impact of reaction parameters consisting of reaction temperature (T rxn), molar ratio of DMC:glycerol (R) and reaction pressure (P) was firstly studied on transesterification DMC to GLC (i.e., 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 as the representation catalyst with a constant catalyst loading of 5 wt% to glycerol). Fig. 4a illustrates the impact of T rxn on the transesterification of DMC to GLC, other parameters were kept constant (R = 2:1, P = 26 bar). At 120 °C, higher GLC yield (Y GLC = 93.2 %) was achieved compared to 100 °C (Y GLC = 88.0 %). However, the increase in T rxn to 120 °C appeared to suppress the GLC selectivity (S GLC = 95.9 %), attributable to the formation of glycidol via decarbonylation reaction (i.e., preferable at a higher temperature) [50,52]. The gas chromatogram results of the activity test [Figure S11 (Supplementary material) showed the byproduct peaked at 30.9 min, and the corresponding mass spectrometric spectrum is displayed in Figure S14 (Supplementary material). For comparison, the reference mass spectrum of glycidol is given in Figure S15 (Supplementary material)]. Besides, the influence of R was conducted at a T rxn of 120 °C, P = 26 bar. As shown in Fig. 4b, the Y GLC obtained at R = 2:1 was 93.2 %, which was higher than the Y GLC obtained at R= 1:1 (Y GLC = 81.0 %). However, R of 1:1 showed improved S GLC over R of 1:2 (S GLC at R = 1:1 and R = 2:1 were 98.8 % and 95.9 %, respectively). Finally, the effect of the P was examined under two pressure conditions (P = 6 bar and P = 26 bar), at R = 2:1, T rxn = 120 °C (Fig. 4c). The corresponding results indicated that the reaction conducted at P = 6 bar showed higher Y GLC over the reaction conducted at P = 26 bar (Y GLC at P = 6 bar and P = 26 bar were 96.2 % and 93.2 %, respectively). Although the glycerol conversion (X Gly) at P = 26 bar is slightly higher than that at P = 6 bar, the S GLC showed conversely lower (at P = 6 bar: X Gly = 96.9 %, S GLC = 99.3 % and at P = 26 bar: X Gly = 97.2 %, S GLC = 95.9 %). These results indicated that the high P condition could be limitated the DMC evaporation, thus, the interaction between the reactants was not affected during the reaction and high conversion of DMC (X DMC) was achieved. However, under higher P condition, the S GLC was reduced which may also due the high T rxn and R of 2:1 conditions (result shown in Fig. 4b). Therefore, at lower P, the actual R value might decrease due to DMC evaporation, resulting in higher S GLC. Subsequenently, the catalytic performance of as-prepared samples and commercial Al2O3 was evaluated at T rxn = 100 °C, R = 2:1, and P = 26 bar (catalyst loading: 5 % to glycerol). Notably, the commercial Al2O3 did not exhibit any product formation under these conditions (see Figure S12 of Supplementary material). Among all the samples, MgO-P displayed the lowest X Gly and Y GLC values (27.0 %). In contrast, MgO@Al-MOF-derived samples exhibited higher catalytic activity in terms of conversion of reactants and Y GLC. Furthermore, the MgO@Al-MOF-derived samples calcined at 550 °C exhibited higher activity compared to samples calcined at 650 °C. The results also revealed that the increase in MgO loading led to the improvement in catalytic performance. Combined with the result depicted in Fig. 5a, a summary of Y GLC versus total basicity of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 6a, revealing that the Y GLC is linearly dependent of the total basicity of the catalyst for MgO@Al2O3 samples. The CaO-containing samples revealed a higher superior performance was obtained than MgO@Al2O3, due to the remarkable enhancement in basicity, especially the strong basic site. Among all catalysts, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 exhibited the highest catalytic performance in terms of YGLC (88.0 %). This can be attributed to the incorporation of CaO significantly enhancing the catalyst's basicity, particularly the strong basic sites, which are critical for glycerol deprotonation. Next, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 also revealed the highest medium basicity, caused by the highest MgO content. This medium basicity positively affects the transesterification of DMC to GLC when using a CaO-loaded catalyst, due to medium basic sites providing surface oxygen anions, which are beneficial for adsorbing active reactants and intermediates during the reaction [14]. Additionally, the 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 catalyst possessed the highest S BET and V pore values among the MOF-derived CaO-containing samples. This can be explained by its lower CaO loading and origin from a MOF precursor. The high S BET translates to a greater number of active sites available for the reaction [53] due to better dispersion of CaO and MgO particles on the Al2O3 support, leading to enhanced molecule adsorption. Although, the 25CaO-25MgO@Al2O3-550 and 40CaO@Al2O3-550 samples also possess higher basicity, their lower medium basicity, S BET and V pore values likely contributed to the observed lower Y GLC values compared to that of the 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550, (Y GLC of 25CaO-25MgO@Al2O3-550 and 40CaO@Al2O3-550 are 73.5 % and 71.1 %, respectively). From the correlation of Y GLC versus the medium basicity of the CaO-loaded catalysts (Fig. 6b), 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 demonstrated the best performance as its highest medium basicity value. The comparison samples, 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP showed lower catalytic activity than Al-MOF-derived samples with the same composition and calcination temperature (Y GLC of 40MgO@AlNP and 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP are 45.7 % and 82.9 %, respectively). Further, the 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP catalyst showed slightly lower S GLC (98.2 %) due to the formation of a by-product, glycidol [Figure S13 (Supplementary material) showed the byproduct peaked at 30.8 min and its mass spectrum is displayed in Figure S14 (Supplementary material); for comparison, the reference mass spectrum of glycidol is given in Figure S15 (Supplementary material)]. Meanwhile, the Al-MOF-derived catalysts exhibited excellent S GLC values (>99 %). On the other hand, the X DMC was found to be half of the X Gly, due to the reaction was conducted at the R of 1:1 condition. Besides, the XRD patterns of the spent Al-MOF-derived catalyst were analyzed (Figure S8, Supplementary material) and the result revealed that the diffraction peaks of the spent catalysts were almost similar to the fresh catalysts, suggesting that there were no alterations in phases or the formation of additional species. Furthermore, the FE-SEM images with EDS mapping of the MOF-derived catalysts after the first reaction cycle (Figure S6 of Supplementary material) revealed that almost no change compared to the fresh catalysts, suggesting good material stability of the catalysts after one cycle. Furthermore, the turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) for GLC production are summarized in Table S3 of Supplementary material. Notably, the TON values exhibit a similar trend to the TOF values. The results show that under the baseline reaction conditions (T rxn = 100 °C, R = 2:1, P = 26 bar), the 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 catalyst achieved the highest TON (17.6) and TOF (4.4 h−1). By increasing the T rxn to 120 °C, the higher TON (19.4) and TOF (4.9 h−1) were observed for the 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 catalyst. According to the reaction mechanism reported previously [24,33,54], this reaction typically proceeds through alkoxide anion. Firstly, the basic site of the catalyst abstracts a proton from one of the primary hydroxyl groups of glycerol, which forms a glyceroxide anion and the conjugate acid of the base. The strong basic sites are advantageous in this step, so the results of CaO-loading showed superior catalytic performance than MgO@Al2O3 [33]. Besides, the medium basicity, primarily influenced by MgO content, provides surface oxygen anions that are beneficial for adsorbing active reactants and intermediates during the reaction [14]. In the next step of reaction, the glyceroxide anion acts as a nucleophile and attacks the carbonyl carbon atom of a DMC molecule, which leads to the formation of a methyl glyceryl carbonate intermediate and a methoxide anion (CH₃O⁻). Then, the methoxide anion reacts with the conjugate acid formed in initial step, regenerating the base catalyst and releasing a molecule of methanol (CH₃OH). Finally, the methyl glyceryl carbonate intermediate undergoes cyclization. The oxygen atom from the remaining secondary hydroxyl group acts as a nucleophile, attacking the carbonyl carbon atom. This cyclization reaction yields the desired product, GLC, and releases another molecule of methanol. Although the Al2O3 exhibited no activity on its own, it plays a supporting role in the catalyst. Obviously, the porous structure of the MOF-derived Al2O3 enhance dispersion of active site and provide a high surface area for the reaction to occur. The stability and the reusability of the best-performing catalyst, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 were assessed. Fig. 7a shows the catalytic performance of 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 for 3 cycles of reaction at R = 2:1, catalyst loading: 5 wt% to glycerol, T rxn = 120 °C and P = 26 bar. The results suggested that the Y GLC and S GLC values were slightly decreased with increasing cycle number. The value of Y GLC was 90.3 % at the 2nd cycle and 89.7 % at the 3rd cycle, which was decreased by 2.9 % and 3.5 % in comparison to the 1st cycle (93.2 %), respectively. The results revealed that the MOF-derived catalyst, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3 has sufficient operation cyclic stability. The XRD was employed for the analysis of the spent sample after 3 cycles of the reaction. As shown in Fig. 7b, the diffraction peaks at 2 θ = 21° and 24° corresponded to calcium diglyceroxide [Ca(C3H7O3)2] in the XRD pattern and peak at 2 θ = 11° was calcium methoxide [Ca(OCH3)2], which were formed due to immersion in glycerol and methanol during reaction [24,55].The results imply that the slight decline in Y GLC during cyclic test was possibly attributable to the ineffective removal of reactant/products and the loss of the catalyst during the recovery process in each cycle. Note that the cyclic catalytic performance of 10CaO-40MgO@AlNP (i.e., the reference sample) was conducted for a comparison, and the results were shown in Figure S16 of Supplementary material, showing that Y GLC decreased from 82.9 % to 80.0 % and 74.0 % in the 2nd and the 3rd cycles, respectively. The difference in the cyclic performance between the the representative catalyst (4 %) and the reference catalysts (9 %) was mainly attributable to the uncertainty in the amounts of catalyst recovered from each cycle. The XPS analysis for 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 before and after 3-cycles reaction was employed, and the spectra were shown in Figure S18 of Supplementary material. The fresh catalyst exhibited Ca 2p peaks at 346.0 eV (2p3/2) and 349.0 eV (2p1/2), corresponding to Ca2+. The peaks at 72.9 eV (2p) and 1302.5 eV (1 s) were assigned to Al3+ and Mg2+, respectively. After 3-cycles reaction, the XPS spectra for the spent 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 catalyst were relatively unchanged in comparison to the spectra of the fresh sample, demonstrating the material stability of the catalyst in term of catalyst surface state. Finally, the catalytic performance of the present MOF-derived catalysts was compared with literature reports. Here, the amount of GLC produced per one gram of catalyst (Z GLC) in Table 4 was calculated in the unit of mmol g-cat−1 as shown in equation S1 (Supplementary material) with the purpose of use in comparison of GLC productivity across different studies. Table 4 summarizes the comparison of catalytic performance with different catalysts over different reaction conditions in DMC transesterification based on the Z GLC and S GLC values. The results demonstrated that Al-MOF-derived catalyst, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 is shown to be promising for the transesterification of DMC to GLC. Compared with CaO [33], CaO-MgO mixed oxide [48], Mg/Al hydrotalcite [35], MgO catalyst [52], Mg/Zr/Sr based mixed oxide [56], YNbO4-200 and SrTiO3-200 [57], 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 showed higher Z GLC (191.5 mmol g-cat−1 at T rxn = 100 °C and 208.9 mmol g-cat−1 at T rxn = 120 °C) and S GLC (>99 %, at T rxn = 100 °C and T rxn = 120 °C). Moreover, with the same conditions of R = 2:1 and T rxn = 120 °C, the 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 sample showed higher Z GLC than YNbO4-200 and SrTiO3-200; After 3 cycles of reaction, the Z GLC of 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 is also maintained higher. For the reported CaO [33], after 3 cycles of reaction, the catalytic performance was reduced significantly (the Z GLC value reduced 4 times compared with the 1st cycle) due to the catalyst deactivation. In contrast to all of the CaO-loading catalysts reported above, the present 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 catalyst demonstrated better stability after 3 cycle tests at T rxn = 120 °C. These results showed that the Al-MOF-derived material, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 exhibit excellent catalytic performance due the enhancement in MgO and CaO dispersion, and subsequent crystallite size reduction. 4 Conclusions A successful synthesis of the MOF-derived base catalysts through a facile and controlled route is achieved in this study. The innovative approach of utilizing MOF-derived samples has proven to be effective in enhancing both specific surface area and basicity for the transesterification of dimethyl carbonate into glycerol carbonate. The findings indicate that the MOF-derived design results in a significant increase in basicity and specific surface area of the hybrid nanostructures composed of Mg-Al and Ca-Mg-Al. The catalyst, 10CaO-40MgO@Al2O3-550 achieved an impressive glycerol conversion (97.2 %), a GLC yield (96.2 %) and high cyclic stability at a reaction temperature of 120 °C. The study demonstrates the promise of employing MOF to fabricate the MOF-derived base catalysts with promising catalytic performance in transesterification of dimethyl carbonate to glycerol carbonate, showing promise for the green chemical synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol carbonate (GLC) offers a range of benefits including biodegradability, versatility, and its potential for carbon capture and utilization. Base catalysts play a crucial role for GLC synthesis by facilitating the activation of reactants, enhancing nucleophilicity, accelerating reaction kinetics, and enabling catalyst regeneration. In this study, metal–organic framework (MOF) derived hybrid structure, CaO-MgO@Al2O3, was developed as a base catalyst to promote transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to form GLC. The results show that hydrothermal plus wet-impregnation routes formed the hybrid nanostructure with homogenously dispersed Ca, Mg and Al elements. Further, the synthesized catalysts showed significantly high specific surface area and basicity (2.656 mmol g−1). High selectivity (>99 %) and high GLC yield (96.2 %; 208.9 mmol g-cat−1) were achievable. This study demonstrated the rational design concept of MOF-derived hybrid structures used in the enhancement of base catalysis for transesterification of DMC to GLC, offering an effective solution with mild reaction conditions and high conversion.
